text: I was making a general statement, not to this game in particular. The gaming market crashed in 1983, and consisted until NES was released in 1985, and it came with a very large game library. But video games really picked up in the 1990's starting in 1992. Even at that point arcades still made a larger profit than home systems at that point. So as I said, the people that created this amazing game had no idea how many would see it, but put effort into anyway. Calm down.
author: bdawkins32

text: historically they did not think that home consoles were the future, infact, Nintendo was financially invested in arcades because at the time(86-89) arcades provided far more money than the more expensive home consoles. text:
The NES was very popular, I'm not doubting that, but it was considered a kid's toy. Adults didn't tend to play it, or even know about it, unless they had families who were also interested in it. 

Back then, the only TV commercials you would see for games were during cartoons. Nowadays, video game ads are played during primetime and during trailers at movies.

Video game fans have undergone a massive demographic change and expansion over the years. You cannot deny that.

text:
The NES era was my era, and I remember it a bit differently. It was big, but to a different kind of audience. My parents and teachers had no idea what a video game console even was, they just knew that the NES was all the rage among kids and is what they all wanted for Christmas.

Nowadays, video games are inescapable and embedded into our culture, even to those who don't play them, and are generally accepted as an art medium along with books and movies. When I was a kid, it wasn't like that.

text:
Sometimes I wonder whether or not the composers of NES tunes had any idea that, in twenty years, people would still be listening to their work and holding it in their hearts as a beloved, timeless classic.

For all we know, it was something they might have thrown together in a few hours for a licensed game on a then-obscure medium of entertainment that they figured only a handful of children would ever hear.

Sometimes the most touching art can come from the unlikeliest of places.

author: Piisuke

text:
Game music doesn't serve the same purpose today as it did back in the day. Back in the days the song had to be catchy and awesome to fill the void left by lacking sound effects. In games now, due to increased memory and computing ability, everything can be made to make noise, reducing the role of music. That's why most game music today isn't as good.

However, there are exceptions. Nintendo and ZUN (maker of Touhou) first come to mind, but are by no means the only decent musicians of today.

text:
@GustavElun hey there, maybe someone already told you but anyway. to loop you have to modify the video url with commands for fullscreen (/v/) , loop and autoplay.
The video url for this very video would look like this:

...youtube.com/v/G_80PQ543rM&loop=1&autoplay=1

So instead of " /watch?v= " you fill in " /v/ " and don't forget " & " as command separators.
it have to be on fullscreen or it will not work

text:
It's by Yoshihiro Sakaguchi, who also wrote music for Mega Man 1 and Mega Man 2.  Most of the Mega Man (Rockman) games had more than one composer.  I know that he wrote the music for HeatMan in Mega Man 2, but I don't know specifically what other pieces he contributed for those games.

Anyway, he's clearly, a composer with a real talent for melody!!  I'd love to know what he's up to now, and hear some more of his work if he's got anything newer.
